thread.title: Officer pepper-sprays passenger at Orlando Airport
thread.title_full: Officer pepper-sprays passenger at Orlando Airport

author: Stephanie Allen
title: Officer pepper-sprays passenger at Orlando Airport
text:
Officer pepper-sprays passenger at Orlando Airport STEPHANIE ALLEN Last updated 09:40, July 23 2015 Richard Snyder via Wikimedia Commons 
Police say an officer pepper-sprayed an airline passenger who refused to comply with instructions to get off the plane for arguing about whether his oversized bag needed to be checked. 
An American airline passenger who refused to check an oversized bag was pepper-sprayed and arrested at Orlando International Airport. 
Calvin Liu, 25, of Brooklyn, New York, was boarding a Delta flight when a flight attendant said his carry-on bag was oversized and needed to be checked, according to an arrest report. 
Liu disagreed and refused to follow the flight attendants commands to get off the plane, so Orlando police were called. 
Officer Ismael Hernandez responded and asked Liu walk onto the jet way, so they could talk about what was going on. 
Liu again refused to get off the plane, saying he travels all the time and has never had issues with the bag. 
He continued to argue and use profanities, as Hernandez asked a flight attendant to get Liu's bag off the plane. 
Liu told Hernandez "that wasn't going to happen," and then pushed the officer with both hands, according to the report. 
Hernandez said he lost his balance, but got a hold of Liu's arm and put him in an arm bar. The officer told Liu he was under arrest and then led Liu to the jet way, where he continued to refuse commands to stop resisting. 
After a continued struggle, Hernandez said he gave a one-second burst of pepper spray to Liu's face. 
Several of Liu's friends, who were on the plane, shouted at the officer that they were filming the incident and to let him go. Ad Feedback 
Hernandez then directed Liu to the ground, where he immediately turned over and held an "aggressive fighting stance,". 
By this time, Hernandez had radioed twice for backup and Liu was shouting to his friends to "film this". 
The officer then drew his stun gun and told Liu "one last time to roll over onto his stomach and place his hands behind his back". 
Liu complied after friends told him "don't worry I got you," Hernandez wrote in the report. 
He was handcuffed and arrested on charges of battery on a law enforcement officer, resisting with violence and disorderly conduct. 
Liu was released from the Orange County jail on bail. 
Orlando Sentinel/TNS
